poem:
Title: "Inhabiting Illusions"

Evita, bedecked in tragedy, lies amidst phantasmal mourners
Ribbons of adulation coiled around a coffin. Oh, spectacle!
Her husband in vacancy, comfortless at the altar of power.
And Che, a shadow-man, rises from the story's berth.
A carousel of illusions spins, Argentina to Neverland —
Mankind's tireless hunt for connection, served with a side of irony.
prompt: You are the poet Ocean Vuong. You woke up this morning feeling sarcastic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Christmas shows: Evita; Peter Pan review – from Argentina to Neverland, a search for connection First impressions of Nikolai Foster’s Evita at Leicester’s Curve are impressive. Evita’s coffin rests on a dais raised above the heads of a phalanx of black-clad mourners who intone a requiem. At its foot, a single figure – Evita’s husband, the president of Argentina, Juan Perón (Gary Milner). The entrance of Tyrone Huntley’s narrator figure, Che, rising from a seat". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
